column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Hi! We went to the Damro factory and after a tour where they explained to us how they make the tea, we had a tea tasting. Both things were good so we decided to buy some boxes of tea to bring home. In particular, I bought one box of Damro Labookellie Cinammon tea and another of Chai tea. Recently, we opened the tea and we were badly surprised by the bad quality of the tea. They don't have taste neither aroma. We felt scammed.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column8: Rushed Tour with Limited Tea Tasting
column11: The tour felt quite rushed, and with the group size it was difficult to hear the guide clearly, which took away from the experience. While the factory visit was interesting, it was shorter than expected. At the end, only one type of tea was offered for tasting, it would have been much better to sample a variety of teas, especially given Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich tea heritage. The scenery is beautiful, but the overall experience could be improved with a slower, more engaging tour and a broader tea tasting.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column8: The WORST experience and BAD customer service by supervisor THUSHARA at Damro Tea Factory!!
column11: The worst experience as a chauffuer guide for the past 10 years. I had a very disappointing experience at Damro Tea Factory. I was served a cake that was clearly expired, which completely ruined the visit and raised serious concerns about food safety. When I brought this to the attention of the staff, the supervisor, Thushara, handled the situation very poorly. There was no proper apology, accountability, or effort to resolve the issue. This level of negligence and unprofessional customer service is unacceptable for a well-known establishment like Damro. I strongly urge management to take immediate action to improve food quality control and customer service standards. ATTENTION MANAGEMENT: Unprofessional customer service by THUSHARA (Supervisor) you‚Äôre about to lose many chauffuer guides and tourists.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We had a nice little tour around the factory. The girl who showed us round was brilliant. Great to see how tea is produced. You can go on a jeep tour and tea plucking experience for a hefty sum of money. We would have had to wait 2 and a half hours before the next tour and the price was so high we didn‚Äôt do it. Once you have been in the factory, they bring you back in to the main area where they show you the colour difference in the teas. You then get shown the tea buying area where they chase you around trying to sell you tea products. They do give you a free cup of tea and we had some cake which was really nice.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column8: Fantastic tea factory tour and tea safari tour experience
column11: Really enjoyed the tea factory tour. This was very interesting and informative. It was free with free teas to sample at the end too. Mesmerised by the process - great to see all this in action. The tea safari tour was also excellent. It is expensive (almost ¬£50 per jeep) but fantastic and unique experience. Bought plenty of tea from the shop too. Very good experience. Very helpful and professional staff.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: In the past, there was a nice and well-made tour of the factory, now too touristy, often only videos are shown so that you end up fixed in the salesroom. The tea, on the other hand, is one of the best

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Stoped off at this tea plantation en route from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. Very busy with lots of tours. I got a lovely lady who gave me the factory tour . I really enjoyed it and learning about the whole process from planting to harvesting and processing. This was followed by a complimentary cup of tea and a slice of delicious tea cake ( small fee). You then had the option of purchasing some teas from the show rooms.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: A visit to Sri Lanka is not complete without visiting a tea planation/factory. And so we visited the Labookelle tea factory (also known as Damro). It was very busy with the car park full of coaches. We went inside and our driver booked us ( no charge) a tour of the factory. After a few minutes, we were taken round by a friendly lady who explained the different stages. This is a real factory so if you are lucky depending on what time you are there, you will see the tea leaves arriving and  going round the stages till it is grounded. After the tour you get treated to some tea (free again). There is a fully stocked shop where you can buy the teas. You will not be able to buy this tea anywhere else as they are not allowed to sell outside the factory! Worth the trip.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column8: If you like tea, this is a must !
column11: Very interesting tea factory tour, we got to pick tea in the plantation. Check for leeches after! We had a piece of fabulous light tea butter cake and got to taste their super fresh BOP tea. After I was able to buy a lot of tea from their efficient tea shop.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column8: The best tour of a tea factory!
column11: This experience was truly out of this world! We had the pleasure being toured around by Hansi, who was an excellent guide and explained the whole process of tea making. She was patient and very friendly, which made our entire experience better. The aroma of tea and being able to see the process of harvesting to drying leaves to making what we see in stores was amazing. 100% recommend buying the VIP package and make sure to try the tea cake with their in-house black tea üëå dont forget to collect their products, which you can only find in this place!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We have visited with the family to the tea lounge and the service staff had rude attitude. They were preventing us using the washrooms even though we have bought tea. And ask to finish our tea soon and leave. I have travelled more than 20 countries and this is kind of worst customer service experienced in sri lanka from a tourist destination. One guy was so arrogant. If you are a foreigner with white skin you should be ok, otherwise I suggest to avoid this place

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We went to the non VIP tea lounge / restaurant on 5th Oct 2025  afternoon hoping for a pleasant experience. But the customer service we experienced was beyond terrible from the staff and one person in particular had extremely rude attitude & completely ruined our evening. Would not ever visit this place & would not recommend to anyone else as well.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I want to thank this person for his great sympathy and kindness in showing us the LABOOKELLIE factory. I don't remember her name.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and the start were very knowledgeable, and professional. Loved learning all about the making of tea from start to finish. The tea and tea cake were delightful. Thank you

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The lounge/show room is located at the Labookellie tea estate factory premises about 20 km from Nuwerelia hill resort town. The emphasis on the name of the tea brand seems to have changed  from being Damroo to Labookellie. The original brand name was Mackwood Labookellie Tea Estate which is about a century old tea brand. The place is crowded with foreigners and the parking lot was too hot with  no tree for shade. The overstretched staff were busy with their hands full. It took considerable time to draw the attention of the staff. The smile from the sales staff is missing. Free pastry and tea were provided for the visitors. The packaging of the tea has improved with airtight containers. The price of the packaged teas have also been considerably jacked up. The company seems to be going in the reverse direction by increasing the  tea prices many fold  while the janatha is clamoring for reduction in prices. Instead of buying good quality but over priced tea packets from the show room, visitors could also explore the other tea show rooms in the vicinity like Rothschilds, Oakray Tea Bush, Ramboda for alternatives. The company could also explore reverting to the original name Mackwood Tea brand if IPR licenses are still held by the present owners. Expensive.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We got to pick tea leaves with the proper picking bags. With three teens in tow, they were not very  keen on stopping at a tea factory. But after the tour (which was very interesting) we went down the back of the carpark, and a guide put the tea picking baskets with straps on our heads, and sent us into the plantation to pick leaves. It was so funny! They were so lovely & took photos and videos. We gave them a tip at the end. The tea pickers earn such poor wages. Happy to tip them & it ended up being one of the highlights.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The "guides" are not interested at all to show you round, when they do its a monologue script and get you through and back to the very expensive shop as quickly as possible. Not worth the time nor effort.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This was an underwhelming and time wasting experience. Don‚Äôt spend your travel time budget on this one. My Sri Lankan partner and I (aka the foreigner) visited for a tea tour. After a 15 min wait for the guide we went on a tour that took 15 mins at most. We listened to some scripted information about tea and found ourselves seated next to the shop with a promise of a cup of tea and an invitation to buy. No discussion, no questions invited, no explanation of why the ‚Äòtour‚Äô did not hit advertised targets. A guy quickly poured tea and was gone. No explanation; I don‚Äôt know what we drank. Boxes of tea were about $50. We left and spoke to a local guide. He said that he‚Äôd overheard staff say it was busy so they should cut our group quickly and get onto the next one. He reported complaints from multiple customers of his. He also said that foreigners get free entry because they‚Äôre likely to buy stuff at the shop. Locals get charged entry because they‚Äôre considered less likely to spend at the shop. We didn‚Äôt pay.  I‚Äôd say they need an overhaul of their customer treatment practices. Nearby is Pedro which has a good reputation, although I did not visit. Heritage tea factory I did visit. We plucked tea leaves in the grounds, walked through a processing plant, had lots of Q and A, then had tea tasting of four kinds of tea. Winner.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: There were so many visitors. At first, we tasted it at Oak Ray, then moved here and toured the factory. The tour is very functional to accommodate a large number of tourists. But the BOP that was then served for free was terrible, and I was even less inclined to buy it. Oak Ray offers a wider variety of tastings and is recommended for its relaxed atmosphere.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The Nuwara Eliya tea factory that we visited is called Damro Labookellie Tea Centre (former Mackwoods) and is the oldest tea centre in Sri Lanka. Their tea bushes are replanted every 100 years on over 5,000 hectares of lush tea plantations. In this tea factory, they make white and black tea, while the green tea is processed in another tea factory and then sent to Damro. All the different kinds of teas have different processes of making and you will be able to learn all about these processes if you do a tea factory tour. The factory tour at Damro is free of charge and ends with delicious tea and cake tasting at the Damro Tea Lounge. While the tour and tea are free, the cake tasting has a small charge and the main profit from the tour comes from tourists buying the tea at the gift shop. You do not need to book the tour in advance and the best way to get here is by organizing the 35min transport with your hotel in Nuwara Eliya.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Nice factory, they let you go everywhere  inside and offer a complimentary tea. You can order things from the menu and we tried only their tea cake but it was so good. We even went to the terraces where the tea is and there was a guy informally distributing baskets for tea plucking and taking pics. Of course we left a tip

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Disappointing Experience ‚Äì Not Welcoming to Asian Women As an Asian woman, I felt deeply uncomfortable and disrespected during my visit to this tea factory. From the moment we arrived, the staff consistently directed their attention only to my boyfriend, who is Western, and completely ignored me. At reception, the woman arranging the tea tour asked only about my boyfriend‚Äôs nationality and spoke solely to him, despite both of us standing there. During the factory tour, another staff member again asked only about his background‚Äîand not mine‚Äîwhile asking other couples (including a Nepali couple) where they were from. Later, in the tea room, the waiter brought the menu and asked only my boyfriend if he wanted to order anything. When he declined, the menu was taken away without even acknowledging me. It felt as though I was invisible. This kind of behavior from a well-known tea brand is incredibly disappointing. No one should feel disregarded or devalued based on their ethnicity or the nationality of their partner. I sincerely hope the management reflects on this and improves their staff training to ensure a more respectful and inclusive experience for all visitors.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Very stunning tea factory just outside the main city area. The factory tour was great, and having a tea and cake looking out to the tea fields was really lovely.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Visited in September 2024. Informative tour of a beautiful factory. Left with several packs of tea, back to Australia. Beautiful loose leaf tea, so much better than the generic brand available in the shops in Aus. Now looking to buy the Damro tea online- I am a convert to the delicious Damro OP tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Great views of the tea plantations. They have tea lounge where they have displayed various varities of the tea grown by the estate. They also take the visitors for a round of the tea factory with a guide who gives a detailed explanation of the whole process.Very educational.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The tour is pretty good, although they sit you down to do a ‚Äúcomplimentary‚Äù tea tasting at the end with all sorts of hidden charges. I also wouldn‚Äôt bother with the tea from the tea shop, it‚Äôs super expensive. All in all I would say it was an interesting stop, but above all it is a tourist trap. I have found out since visiting that EVERY SINGLE ONE of the tea factories exploit Tamil Indian people for working the tea leaves, paying them barely enough to live. I wish I hadn‚Äôt gone.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Travel with Dimma to Damro Tea in Labukele while driving NuwaraEliya  and  feel the Srilankan uniq Vibrance and feel like Wow.Visit Srillanka.This is best time

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Nuwara Eliya is one of the seven major production areas of Ceylonty. Here Damro (formerly Macwood) is the second oldest tea plantation in Sri Lanka and owns more than 5,000 hectares of tea plantations. You can experience tea picking in the tea plantation, visit the tea factory, and taste tea. The shop also sells various kinds of tea leaves produced in this factory.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Paid for the plantation tour, and as soon as we left it started raining heavily. 10 minutes in our driver suggested going back and asking for a refund, which we agreed was a good idea. On arriving back the staff and manager were very rude and unwilling to give even a partial refund, saying we had not been forced to do the tour, and that they don‚Äôt offer refunds. Very unpleasant experience overall, would not recommend. It‚Äôs a shame because the driver seemed genuine and friendly so could‚Äôve made a mistake.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Went on a plantation tour, where it started raining, and our driver said to turn back after 10 mins and get a refund, which was then denied upon discussing with the people inside. They claimed that we had had the full experience despite the receipt showing we only paid for it half an hour before, and not having chance to even pick our own tea leaves, they repeatedly claimed we had got the full experience and no refund could be given, contradicting what the driver had told us.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The green tea plantation is stunning. ü§ç You can have some beautiful pictures picking the green leaves. The staff is very careful with the clients and we did not pay for anything because we were with our sri lankan tour guide.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The "leadership" has max. It took 10 minutes. It's free, but you don't really see anything. Especially no employees.  It's reasonable to assume it's an abandoned factory. Afterwards there is a cup of tea to sample but then you are urged to buy (overpriced). For a lot of money (60‚Ç¨) you can pick tea yourself and get photographed. The experience is not really worthwhile. Maybe there are better alternatives?

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Had a tour in the factory, by a sardine lady, then we were allowed to taste tea. You could also buy tea there and have done that.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I originally planned to go to Pedro but canceled those plans based on reviews and tried Damro instead. The best decision I'd made. Damro not only offer a free tour of their factory, but their knowledgeable staff cover the tea processing process extremely well. For 20,000LKR, you can hire a jeep and go on a one hour safari. This also includes a tea tasting at the end. Good value we thought if going with six people like we did. The guide was amazing, really cared about his job, and went the extra mile to take photos for us, answer questions, etc. The highlight for us was learning and trying to pick tea ourselves in the fields. We all have a big appreciation for the work goes into each cup we drink. I highly recommend that if you want to know Sri Lankan tea, go to Damro!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: There was nothing interesting - it was around 15 mins of tour which ended at the tea shop.  Variety of tea available for sale.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I love tea and this place was everything I hoped. Our guide that took round the factory was friendly and very knowledgeable. We were not rushed and could take lots of photos and ask as many questions as we wanted. Wish we had picked tea leaves ourselves but the weather wasn't great . The tea room and cakes were gorgeous. I didn't feel pressured into buying anything. Didn't take too long either and the cafe and decked area offer fab views.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This was a free tour, you could pay a tip at the end if you wanted to but there was no pressure.  We were asked to sit and wait 5 minutes for an english guide who was very good and she explained the process to us very clearly and we saw quite a lot.  I was impressed with the tour and felt it was quite comprehensive. 150 year old factory and the wood the use in drying process.  You get a tea tasting at the end and can buy teas if you want to, but again there was no pressure to.  Got to purchase a slice of cake to go with your tea which was really nice.  We had already watched the tea ladies picking the tea, so this was ample for us and enjoyed very much.  We could also take photos which other tours dont allow.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Must stop in SriLanka to taste your famous tea. It is the most important manufacturer in the country and guarantee for your purchases. The visit is brief and without anything extraordinary, more than the large production capacity. Then you taste tea, although first tea they put the normal, and if you want something special you have to order it. It has varieties for all tastes and pockets, and its store sells multiple formats, ideal for you or for gifting.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: It's a completely overflowing, short promotional event. A quick look at the drying and sorting and you are through. As a tea fan you like the subsequent tasting.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This is a tourist trap for sure, the very quick tour of the tea making plant was informative and the guide was helpful;. I think the tour should have shown you some actual tea picking  and a walk in the tea bush fields which very close by. The after tour free tea was nice but hurried. Lots of variety on sale, expensive but like most we bought a packet as a souvenir . Lastly yhre Health and Safety in the factory wasn't good, no belt guard and a big wheel at knee level spinning vey fast, accidents waiting to happen.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This is considered one of the oldest tea Estates in sri lanka. The teas were very good and we enjoyed the tea tasting ,the delicious cake and the charming ,professional service given to us by Shobithan our server. He made us feel very welcome and went out of his way to see to all our needs.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Very interesting short tour, which started with our group being given bags for gathering tea leaves and learning about the wages for the women whose occupation is gathering them. After a tea tasting of several varieties, in a pure state (versus with additives, which is how the teas are normally sold, once purchased in bulk at the auctions), there was the shop, where many of my additional questions were answered. I enjoyed the Golden Tips Tea the best and bought 2 boxes at 50 g each for about $30 each. That seemed expensive, but checking prices once back in the US, I see that it is not readily available and the price is around $75. The quality of what I brought back was very good, and I purchased green and black teas as well.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: It‚Äôs a money factory. We arrive and it‚Äôs full of people waiting to be integrated in a group to go to see the tea fabrication process. We where with a small group with a very professional lady that explain and the steps to make the tea, it‚Äôs like 25 minutes and it‚Äôs done. After the send u to try the tea, only one kind is a available and we don‚Äôt even try because no table was available. If u are going expecting to have the experience of see how the ladies collect the tea you can do it but it‚Äôs 70‚Ç¨ per person for one your. Quite disappointing

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The views were amazing. The factory tour was free and informative. However, the jeep safari tour of the tea plantation is very expensive and not worth the money. It is basically a jeep ride over narrow, bumpy road a few photos of you picking some tea leaves. We were in the jeep for 50mins of the hour tour and 10mins picking tea leaves and having photos. A total waste of money and time!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Was a nice tour, wasn‚Äôt that long - was more like a selling pitch but the views were amazing, the inside of the factory was okay, the shop was nice. Complimentary tea was good too. Glad we visited as was in the area not sure I‚Äôd go out my way completely!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Super exciting tour. Short and simple, gave really nice insight into tea production.Good tea and cake. Very friendly people.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: As far as tea factories go I think Damro is the better option. Found it to have more scenic surrounds and the staff were more authentic and professional. Enjoyed a cup of tea and the famous tea cake after the tour. Tour was less than 20-minutes as a solo traveller.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Summary, quick and even inaccurate presentation of how tea is produced. The purpose is only one: to take you there to sell you tea. Everything else doesn't matter.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: FREE TEA FACTORY TOUR AND TEA TASTING (charges of 25,000 LKR only if you take the jeep up to the tea plantation). A good place to go for the Tea factory tour, the tour and the tasting is FREE but if you want to go to the Tea plantation with the help of a jeep where they will click your pictures plucking tea with a basket around a picturesque background, it would cost your 25,000 LKR as on 08.01.2025. They will try to "SCAM" you to take the jeep first and make it seem like that's the only way to go for the tea tour, just say no that you don't want the jeep if you don't want to spend 25,000 LKR and say that you are here for the FREE TEA FACTORY TOUR. hope this helps...

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We have a guided tour about the work steps of tea - from picking to cupping in German it was very interesting to see what is done here Finally we got three cups of tea for tasting for free The very good cake was to pay The adjacent shop invited you to shop but you could not have.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Tea factory tour was quick and good. The cafe had excellent pizzas and free tea tasting. The safari was an unnecessary tourist trap of LKR 20K and yielded only 2-3 photo opps. Total waste of money! Even the kids were bored. Driver was reckless too. Most of such photos one can get for free anyway as there are many tea gardens all around where one can simply climb up and get similar pics.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: View nice, walking tour but just buy nothing in the store!!!!!! The place is overpriced. You can't give anything back.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: On the drive up to Nuwara Eliyah from Kandy, this is a favourite stop for tour operators. Beware, it is a sophisticated scam. You are taken to a well appointed lounge with a mesmerizing array of tea varieties on display and you are served tea in a teapot and cup - elegant and tasty. Great views and photo ops. Plus a rush trhough the tea factory. Naturally you would like to buy some tea- overpriced. I bought quite a selection advertised as Broken Orange Pekoe. When I reached home and opened the paxck, it was full of fine dust tea. This is a third of the cost of leaf tea. In most places this would be considered a dishonest trade practice. Tip: park your car, use the toilet, have tea offered and take some snaps. But DONT buy the tea here.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The area around Damro is spectacular, with tea grown on the side of mountains the scenery is really good. Couple of lookout points for nice photos. You can also follow the path down by the river and get a close up look of the tea. Inside the factory it‚Äôs a tourist trap, it‚Äôs very busy and you feel that they are just trying to get you to buy overpriced tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Interesting short tour. Obviously a tourist focussed place with high priced tea. We bought some basic tea and not the way overpriced teas. A real pity that these places treat visitors like fools and price gouging tourists does seem like a sport in Sri Lanka. We bought some great tea in Pettah market where all the locals shop for a fraction of the price.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: A nice educative visit to the tea factory. The highlight of the trip is the free tea at the cafe upstairs and you can order their pizzas and tea infused cakes which are quite tasty.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Nice place. They have excellent tea. They teach you all the types of tea they have, depending on the quality and cut.  They have a shop selling their tea which is of excellent quality.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The price of the tour to the factory is too expensive is 30 euros per person, it is interesting the explanation they give you, they give a free Te rate which you must accompany with something of the letter q they present you, the road to know the tea plantations is very deteriorated, you go all the time taking leaps, I hope that the wages they pay their workers of the plantations are decorous because it is a very hard work that women do in the sun , I did not see anywhere q could rest, drink water or eat something or q I saw no signs that they had anywhere to rest or go to the bathroom at any time. I get a very bad impression of the conditions of the workers on the plantation.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We enjoyed this tour of the tea plantation and tour of the processing area. Tour guides are well informed and can answer any questions you may have. From seeing the ladies picking the tea, the drying and sorting process to the actual cup arriving at your table is an experience  worth taking. The "tea cake" was delicious too. Lovely views over the plantation. Their is a shop where the various teas can be purchased at reasonable prices.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We were at Damro's on the decision of our driver who advised against the other producers of the place as he also had to stock up on you. Unfortunately I am very disappointed with the purchase. The reasons are as follows: the finest teas they were exorbitantly priced so I bought Planter's Whisper 2,800, BOP Labookellie 1,500 and the Green Tea Labookellie 1,450. Except for Planter's, the other teas are powder. If I wanted to buy this kind of tea I could go to a Cargills and save a lot of money. The tea we tasted during the visit was certainly of superior quality. Conclusion: do not get advice from the driver if he insists on going only to places and not to others (there are many manufacturers), read the buyers' reviews the day before and you will not be disappointed. Kind regards.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The view of the tea estate was great. Also, the tea cake was delicious and went well with the complimentary tea. This is a great place to visit and learn about tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Explore the iconic Damro Labookellie Tea Factory with Cultural Ceylon Tours. Nestled in the lush hills of Nuwara Eliya, this historic factory offers a unique insight into Sri Lanka's world-renowned tea production. Witness the intricate process from leaf to cup and enjoy a refreshing cup of Ceylon tea amidst breathtaking views.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Today we went to Damro with an organized tour and the experience was quite bad. Explanations of simple and quick guides and worst store prices. Totally abusive. A trap for full-blown tourists. I recommend not buying anything there. In the normal shops of the village, you can find teas of other brands for a third of the price and with a quality equal to the Dumro. We were not even given a guided tour of the plantation. A real disaster visiting.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This beautiful estate is as much a tourist factory as it is a tea factory. We initially went into the locals side, which was really interesting and has informative signs and samples out for smelling. However we were quickly ushered to the ‚ÄúVIP area‚Äù despite saying we didn‚Äôt want a VIP experience. The VIP area was essentially a clinical shop with extremely high prices. I think they were running tours as well, but we were too small a group for anyone to bother with when there were bus groups coming through.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We had high hopes for this tour which was organised through Trailfinders/Walkers Tours. However, we were left feeling disappointed: Pros Informative & interesting tour of the factory Free cup of tea after the tour Good view of the tea plantation Cons Our tour had far too many people - around 20 people (other tours only had 2-3 people) Difficult to see and hear what was going on (one elderly woman left the tour within 5 minutes) Very expensive & overpriced tea in the shop No option to see the plantation other than an overpriced jeep safari Room for improvement Charge an entry fee Allow visitors to see the tea plantation by walking and not just paying an extortionate price for a Jeep

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The tour itself was informative Tea in the shop was above average prices but diday good presents Jeep tour of plantation was very expensive so we swerved it Our guide took us which had I know. It was extremely tourist orientated I would has asked he took us elsewhere

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: A truly magnificent visit to impressive tea fields. It was a rewarding experience to discover the tea culture and taste different varieties. This place, located in Sri Lanka, is known worldwide for its production of quality tea. The tasting and tour is free, possibility to buy tasting teas.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We were on our round trip here at the Dambro tea factory. There was a small free tour at the beginning where you were shown and explained all the production steps. Afterwards we each got a free cup of tea of your choice and additionally three other variants. However, these were only available per table, which did not bother us personally. Km adjacent shop you could, if you wanted, buy the different teas. There was no compulsion to buy here.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We already visited Bleufields tea-factory, but this was quite complementary. Damro is bigger, produces much more tea which enabled us to see all processes in action. We also booked the tea-safari, which was better than we expected; you go deep and high into the fields, which offers great views. You also get to ‚Äòpluck‚Äô some tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: 50,000LKR was taken out of my wallet during safari tea tour organised by Damro tea factory. My husband and I left the jeep for 5 min to pick tea leaves and take pictures and we were told to leave my handbag in the jeep. Big mistake! The Damro jeep driver helped himself and denied it when we spoke to the management who ignored us. Very bad service, DO NOT VISIT THIS FACTORY

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: It was a pleasant as well interesting tour of the tea estate. The guidie explained in detail the process of tea leaves and tea making.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Guide kept on saying this is the best among all other factories, not sure how reliable this is but the girl explaining the process was good, they make black and white tea here. Wanted to do a trekking but it was raining hard and their jeep ride was quite expensive to be honest (20000 LKR for 1 hr). Tea sold here is quite expensive when you compare with the supermarkets i guess it's alright if you wanted the pure organic non-blended ones.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Amazing tea Experience at damro..They provides free factory visit to the tourists and their hospitality is the best part ‚ù§

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Very interesting tea factory tour, not too long and very informative. Now we know everything we need to know about black tea, green tea, white tea and golden tea, the plants and the processes involved in producing something we take for granted every day. We had a nice piece of cake and complimentary tea at the end, for a total of around ¬£2, which is incredible for a place like this. We bought some tea in the shop. Yes, prices may seem high to some, but it‚Äôs not all about the price, it‚Äôs about the experience, the uniqueness of the occasion and the friendly treatment, all of which we got. Highly recommended.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This tea farm is certainly a tourist attraction with European prices when it comes to buying tea. Yet it is absolutely worth the experience: the scenery is breath-taking, the small tour is super interesting, you can pluck some tea yourself of the tea plants or simply just take beautiful pictures and enjoy the vibes. Being so high in altitude certainly adds to the beautiful landscapes. You can try different teas and also buy for home. Yes,it is overpriced when it comes to the premium options, but the rest was pretty ok. Total duration of the visit with some tea drinking is 60-80 minutes

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: A great place to visit.  I was part of a tour. The lovely lady that showed us around had perfect English so was easy to understand   It is amazing to learn about the drying process etc kept to very precise timing   Also fun to have a go at picking the tea leaves   Highly recommend as something a little different

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Our guide took us to the tea factory & we thoroughly enjoyed the fairly short tour, tea & cake. We had already stopped by the roadside to meet, tip & have photos taken with some friendly tea pickers. The tea selection was very varied & interesting to try. The cake was excellent too. Nice room to sit in & the shop displays are very nice. Some reviews are negative, what do people expect at a tea factory? These people are poor, they work hard for low pay. Go there & support them & their families.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I opted for the Milk Tea, which was excellent, but a bit on the pricey side at Rs 300 per cup.  The same goes for the tea cake - delicious, but Rs 300 is a bit steep.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Fantastic. Excellent place with a view of the plantations. Indelible memories. It is possible to visit the factory and taste the tea...

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: One of the larger tea plantations in the area, well geared to for tourists. There‚Äôs a free tour of the factory or a tour with some tea tasting and a trip up into the plantations which costs around ¬£25 pp (2024)

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: It was a very unfortunate experience: The tour of the tea fields at Damro Tea costs a whopping more than $60 per vehicle; With this price and the prestige of this company I thought this type of thing would not happen. However, at the beginning of the tour, when I got out of the car to take a photo, the driver (who continually encouraged me to get out of the car) took the opportunity to take my wallet out of my bag. When I quickly returned I saw him throw the wallet to the ground when he caught it. "in flagrante": he only had time to throw it to the ground but not to take money. When I returned from the tour I spoke to the manager, I told him what had happened to me and he told me that he was going to take stockings. He seemed like a reasonable man, so I suppose he kicked out this undesirable person, but, in case that wasn't the case, my recommendation is to always have your belongings under control in case you tour the tea fields or, better yet, go to another field. of the many tea shops in Nuwara Eliya where they take care not to have criminals on staff and take care of their visitors..

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The drive to the place is bumpy and the tour isn‚Äôt a must do on my list, but the tea itself is amazing! We bought a bunch of boxes to bring back and use as gifts. The desserts are also excellent

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We came here on recommendation. There are always free tours on offer, which are entertaining and free, but don't take long. The process of making white and black tea is explained. At the end there is a free sample (breakfast tea). If you want cake: 450LKR (very tasty!!) Extra sample of other types: 250LKR each. In the shop you are not pressured to buy anything. And we really liked it.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I visit the factory on factory on 14th January. Fast but nice introduction with a english good speaking woman who showed us the place in 5 minutes. Is not possible to visit the plantations unless you pay 80$ to visit with a jeep. The problem was the prices and quality of products. bought this ‚Äúcotta guard stone‚Äù and wait to arrive at home to unwrap it. There‚Äôs not a really smart way to open it, there‚Äôs a small hole with the tea inside a plastic bag inside. you can‚Äôt take it off. so the black tea is inside this sculpture made of terracotta, when opening it it was already cracked (not my fault, it was packed in 3cm of plastic wrap). when I opened the package, a piece of the box came out. such a pity, terrible quality. I would recommend people go somewhere else to buy the products, as it will be way cheaper and probably with a better quality

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Efficient visit and tasting. If you buy however beware because no prices are shown and the checkout cashiers unhelpful. No exchange once they have posted the sale.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: All the groups stop here, or at other large HILL COUNTRY tea factories. Let's just hope there is local capital, and not just British capital invested here. The production process that leads to obtaining green tea, black tea, or white tea (silver or gold variant) was explained in Italian. We were offered a cup of tea, in two variations, and then, for those who wanted it, we proceeded to purchase it. FABULOUS surrounding landscape!!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We just did the free 30 minute factory tour which was excellent. Couldn‚Äôt justify time or cost (c. 32$ each) to go tea picking. Very simple process that has been going at this site for more than 140 years using much of the original machinery! All followed by a (again free) tea tasting. On the road to Nuwara Eliya from this facility you can see some of the 600+ ladies employed as tea pickers across the 1200 acre estate. Makes you appreciate hard work - these folk have to pick 18kg of tips each / day!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I visited the Damro tea centre in Nuwara Eliya.  As soon as I entered I wasn't allowed to have a cup of tea as I need some sort of membership that costs Rs 1,500. I was a bit disappointed as I wanted to try and buy some silver tip tea and the only way to do is to pay the fee.  It was a bit embarassing as I took a seat and then get up and walk out. They need to put a ticket counter so that people entering the tea room could buy the ticket first.  Very disappointed as in the past I never paid any money to have a cup of tea. You probably need to pay for the cup of silver tea on top of this fee.  Will never go there.  Visited another tea estate named Pedro Estate and they even served a nice cup of black tea for free of charge.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Ok... the factory visit was short as there's not so much to visit, 1 Drying room and 1 tea plant distribution room.... from there to the shop and tea degustation. the tea is ok (variety, smell, flavours) and also the landscape have nice pictures. Have to visit because the location is a must but do not expect to see nothing out of the usual

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We decided to stop here as we read some good reviews, however the teas that we tried were just not good, whereby this is supposed to be a premium brand. Don‚Äôt try to ask questions about tea because shop assistants don‚Äôt have a clue, other than this tea is strong, this tea is healthy, this tea is good if you need to give a present. Ok. This is a very big business, they have huge plantations and a brand new building however it is very sad to learn about the conditions of underpaid workers.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I was taken to this tea factory as part of a tour. The lady explained about the different types of tea being manufactured and processed in the factory. Historically, Indian labour was brought by the British to work in the tea plantations. Now there are the same families third fourth generation labour still working there. They have been exploited quite badly. The tea processed is auctioned by the government and then bought by big manufacturers who blend the tea to make it cheaper. The factory was empty when I went but they do serve a nice cup of tea and there is a shop on the premises.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We really enjoyed our experience here! The tour guide spoke perfect English and was really informative on the tea making process. The tour was really interesting especially if you love tea like us. The tea and cake at the end was amazing and there is plenty of choice on which tea you can buy.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I have visited this place several times with my family, but this time we decided to take a tea plantation tour. This was the day that I learned a lot about tea and tea pickers' lives. That was so interesting and made me to explore more about Sri Lanka tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We had read that this was a good address to visit as a tea factory. We had our tuk tuk driver take us there, Upon arrival, a hostess will meet you and ask if you would like to go on an excursion. for 15,000 rupees (‚Ç¨43, 3 of us) we received a 20-minute tour with explanation in the factory and then an hour-long safari through the plantation where we could pick ourselves and the ladies at work could see. The lady who gave the explanation had a terribly annoying voice so I quickly dropped out. She explained the process itself very well and you could see how they worked behind glass. Then we went for a cup of tea in the tearoom before being picked up for the tour. The boy who served us asked if we wanted black tea and if we wanted a piece of cake. I asked if I could drink green tea and I was the only one who wanted a piece of cake. He didn't say anything about it costing money and there was no menu on the table so I thought it was part of our tour. Until the bill arrived that included my green tea and cake. I said I wasn't going to pay it because nothing was said. Our tuk tuk driver came to pick us up to say he was joining us for the ride. Very nice, I thought. Then he doesn't have to wait so long. Got up and went outside. We set off in a comfortable jeep-like car with an open roof. We drove up between the tea fields. We were given a tea leaf in our hands and were allowed to help pick what one of the ladies was doing. we were given a basket on our backs to put the tea leaves in and left our backpacks in the car. I don't know if our tuk tuk driver conspired with the tour driver but they went into our backpacks. They opened our front pockets for me and my son. Afterwards I missed my beautiful pocket knife and my son had ‚Ç¨50 taken from his wallet. My daughter and I both had a bag with our money in it, so they couldn't reach it. We only found this out at the hotel. The ladies who work for this company have to pick 20 kg per day and then receive ‚Ç¨3.50. We saw them dragging the heavy bags while tourists (us) drive past them in a car. Let them use those cars to transport the tea. This looks like slave labor. It was a worthless trip that didn't last an hour and for which we paid too much money. We might as well have driven up in our tuk tuk. When I returned I asked for my money back. I was unable to speak to a manager and did not get my money back. After all, we had already had the excursion. I left pissed. While we were on our way, our tuk tuk driver received a phone call. They called because the bill for the tea and cake had not yet been paid. I said again that I am not going to pay for it. So, watch your stuff when you go picking and you now know not to have another tea and cake if you don't feel like paying extra.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Our private driver suggested we go here rather than our planned stop at Bluefields Tea Centre. It was a public holiday for Diwali so the factory and tea picking was not operating. It is free of charge to be taken on a guided tour of the factory. A very slick operation with well spoken guides and a very smart tea room with lovely atmosphere, great views and comfortable table and chairs.  We were able to try Gold Tips and Silver Tips teas which are both very expensive. The hope is you will buy something in their shop and lots of people do including locals. On exiting we were asked if we wanted to buy anything and politely declined and nothing was said. Our driver received a bag of tea for bringing us which I understand happens in all the tea centres. The staff, beautiful view, tea sampling and tour were excellent.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Madhi explained in detail the entire process for producing tea in Italian. The scent you breathe is truly inebriating. After the visit, an excellent cup of tea is offered and, obviously, you can buy the tech which is offered in different solutions and prices. In my opinion it's a good buy!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This was our first visit to a tea growing region, plantation and factory. This region of Sri Lanka is spectacular and beautiful and the tea plantations are a lovely site, including the Damro one. Not a famous brand, but the majority of their tea product is sold into the wholesale market, with the rest sold as own brand on site. The tour of the 100+ year old factory showed the simple process of producing black tea; green tea is produced elsewhere by a slightly different process.  At the end of the tour you are taken to the tasting room, where you can taste the full range of teas from white to black for free. The tasting room is conveniently located next to the shop!!!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Beautiful tea garden and great tour The cafe is lovely where you can enjoy a selection of the teas and they have great chocolate cake The views from the factory are amazing, you can witness tea picking right in front of you The factory tour we had was brilliant The lady who took us around was so knowledgeable and really explained the whole Process I am so much more grateful for my tea now!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Accessible place with ample parking space. Good service with quality tea products. You will be ushered by the guides there.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Best Tea factory in nuwaraeliya. We  can reach on the way from gampola to nuwaraeliya road when pass the ramboda. You can take factory tour and Tea garden tour in there. Having tea with cake best at the evening.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Loads of tourists at this place where you are taken to a short tour of the facilities and then provided the opportunity to taste some teas before shopping. The teas are priced a bit higher than other parts of Sri Lanka but having learnt they export 80% and provide tea leaves to big names such as Dilmah and Lipton and don‚Äôt sell retail might be beneficial to buy

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: When they heard that we were Italian they entrusted us to a guide who spoke Italian and learned it simply by listening to tourists. Very good at explaining the whole process that revolves around tea. At the end of the tour they offered us a tasting of really good Black tea. You can purchase sweets to accompany. At the end there is also a shop where you can buy different types of tea. If you're on the road I recommend a stop in this Factory. The experience takes a maximum of 40 minutes, excluding all the time you want to stay and taste tea in the dedicated room.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We stopped here on our way from Kandy to Nanu Oya. The views of the tea fields are amazing. We had a short free tour around the factory which was really interesting and informative. Then they offer a complimentary cup of tea which was delicious. Bought a couple of items in their shop, more photos then on our way! Perfect place to stop for half an hour on a journey through the mountains

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Factory tour ok, swerved safari as only three of us to fund ¬£40 six seater deal, customer service ok as had place almost to ourselves so taken on tour after a minute when tourists arrived to make up a group, taken straight to table for taster, only didnt buy more as no tasters for product range, shop at gift shop prices but not outrageous.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: When we visited (weekends are generally more crowded), the general tea shop was too cramped and we decided to visit their (adjoining) new wing/tea shop with more space and comfortable seating. Found out that they charge a fee of LKR 1,500 for a package that includes a piece of cake, a cup of tea, two packets of tea leaves and a private tour of the tea factory. Thought it was reasonable and our server (Prabhu) was excellent, a young man relatively new to the place but very attentive and had a high level of enthusiasm about the work. Recommend for people who are interested in learning about tea processing and varieties of tea, also buy good quality teas.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Lovely excursion but bought 100gms of tea for ¬£35. The price was in Sri Lanka Tupperware so was confused but think the cost of the tea was excessive

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The amazing tea experience  and most delicious tea cake i ever tasted. mindful surrounding and friendly staff. everyone should taste the real tea taste of Sri Lanka in Damro Labukellie.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Lovely stop off to Nuwara Eliya with excellent tea service and the opportunity to buy tea gifts. Well worth visiting

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Found this was more enjoyable than I thought. The factory tour was really interesting to see the processes. Our guide was so lovely and very informative. We‚Äôre from England so love tea and this was the best we ever tasted! We know now all the stuff at home is blended but the single origin premium quality they produce is so good. Definitely recommend this place and the tea they sell there is reasonably priced so we bought some to bring home

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Stopped her for overview of tea making process which began here 1928 by James Taylor didn‚Äôt realize everything picked by hand by imported Indian people The tea tasted amazing much better than what we get in the states and the air around plantations smell of tea

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We enjoyed our factory tour and tea tasting very much. Our guide was delightful, and the surrounding scenery was gorgeous. There is a large shop where you can purchase tea in various containers but no pressure to buy. Tour is free although we tipped our guide generously.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I can‚Äôt recommend this place. It‚Äôs a tourist money machine. Big bus groups running through the place. Loud, crowded and no nice vibe. I waited for one hour to get a tour through the factory. After asking me to wait nobody came back to me so I left. I would recommend you to go to smaller privat places where they show you how they produce the tea by hand without machines. Watch a YouTube video how the industrial production goes. I think that‚Äôs enough. The tour through the factory is for free. There is also a tour through the tea plantations for 15.000 Rs (1h).

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: The tour was good (free of charge) & the tour guide had great English. She explained the process of how they made tea in the factory. They also provide a complimentary black tea at the end. There is a tea shop but you do not feel pressured to buy anything. Scenery around the factory is beautiful.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Very interesting and a very knowledgeable guide. We loved hearing and seeing the process followed by nice cup of tea in the guest room. Even the shop is very well priced and it even makes the royal family‚Äôs personal tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We visited Damro as it was recommended by our driver and it was a great tour, incredibly informative! We were driven into the plantation, where there are some wonderful viewpoints and picture opportunities and then got to pick tea ourselves, with our guide also explaining which leaves were used for what tea. Afterwards a lovely employee showed us around the factory, whilst quite a brief tour it was informative and interesting and she was very nice! We were served some tea to try for free and I also had the tea cake (400 lkr = 1.10$) which was very nice!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: I don't know, what happend to the place, but it was ABSOLUTE waste of time.. A company guide rushed a group of us through the factory (like 5' tour) Then we were shown the area where all different teas were available for sale. I asked the guide nicely, if we can get some more information and even see the plantation and other staff, she told us they are busy, but she can give us the tour again, we saw they are not busy, so we told her, we can see they are not busy, so she told us it is not safe to go to the field, it was raining and it's not safe (it was not raining for a week). So we got the feeling they don't care about anything else then sales, so we left very dissapointed. It's not worth of visit at all! There is a large decking viewing area at this establishment.. Where you can look at the rows of tea bushes, under it you will find the poor locals, begging for you to throw a few notes over the handrail of the decking. You only find out information once you actually leave and the guide explains more.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Well organised tour. We were picked up from our hotel and driven to the factory for the tour. The tour was really interesting and enjoyable. Highly recommended

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Stopped here on our tour. I have to say this was an exceptional tour with a very knowledgeable guide. Very informative. We have visited tea plantations in India, Kerala, China and Nepal and I have to say this was by far the best experience The staff in the shop were very helpful. Purchased some beautiful teas at a very good price. Would highly recommend stopping off here.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: For centuries known as Mackwood Labookellie Tea Estate, the name of the tea estate has been changed to Damro Tea Estate recently on transfer of the estate to the Damro business group. The showroom is located in situ at Labookellie Tea Estate right on the main road from Kandy to Newerelia. The huge bill boards near the entrance are helpful to easily  locate the show room. The showroom has been extensively renovated with ample parking space and comfortable seating area. The top quality of the original Mackwood Labookellie Tea Estate is still maintained. The visitors are given free tea tasting of the single estate tea from the estate. The quality of tea is very good and the prices are quite reasonable. Visitors from India can consider taking many packets of Indian sweets like Son Papdi which is in huge demand by the sales executives at the showroom. The sales executives are polite, smiling and neatly dressed in traditional Sri Lankan attire. Highly recommended for the conoseuers of authentic single estate Sri Lankan tea.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Stopped for a tour and to b sold local tea, but it was a pleasant stop. There was a short interesting tour of the factory and then a tea tasting. Unfortunately we were only offered English Breakfast Tea when there was an opportunity to sample some of the more exotic teas on sale.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Our driver chose this particular tea factory to visit, this was the only one we had time to visit so have nothing to compare it with in regards to having a better experience elsewhere.  We went on a Sunday which is the only day of the week where the factory is not running so you don‚Äôt get to see any of the processes or ladies out in the plantations picking tea.  The tour through the factory was very informative but somewhat rushed and difficult to hear as this is a very popular tour spot, so other groups are hot on your heels as you make your way around the factory.  The tour is free and you are given a complimentary cup of tea on completion, your guide will also try and upsell you in to purchasing an overpriced piece of cake to go with your cuppa.  You are not pressured into purchasing tea however if you wish to buy tea the shop was extremely busy and understaffed so hard to get any info on any tea that you want to purchase as well as pricing.  We did find out why our driver took us to visit this particular factory as we noticed as soon as we purchased he disappeared and came back with his free packet of tea. The outlook of all the tea plants for as far as the eye could see was stunning and we did gain useful info regarding the process from the tour, would have preferred to visit when the factory was working.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We visited on a Saturday morning and the drive from Nuwara Eliya to Damro is not far but the views was absolutely breathtaking as it was a clear morning and seeing the people working in the plantations was an amazing sight. At the tea factory we were taken on a tour by a very knowledgeable guide and we truly enjoyed it and learned a lot. We then had a very nice cup of tea to finish off the tour. They do offer tours (safari) into the tea plantations but we did not do that. Would recommend a visit. We did find the shop a bit expensive.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Having visited this establishment on a Sunday... ( CLOSED...), which the guide we used didn't know.. ABSOLUTE waste of time.. A company guide literally rushed a group of us through the factory.. It was empty of employees, and so we saw nothing of how the process works... It took no more than 10mins to go through to the area where we Began the tour.. Then we were shown the the area where all different teas were available for sale.. So for me it's purely a 'sales push..' Total waste of time in my opinion There is a large decking viewing area at this establishment.. Where you can look at the rows of tea bushes.. Under this decking you will find the very very poor locals, who have no income or jobs.. Begging for you to throw a few notes over the handrail of the decking.. The tea pluckers earn around 2,000 rupees per day.( aprox ¬£5.) They have to pluck 20kgs per day for that pay.. So sad .. Would never return.. You only find out information once you actually leave and the guide explains more...

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Learnt so much about how different types of tea are manufactured. Guide was brilliant and extremely knowledgable, answering all of the questions we had about the process at the plantation. Tour lasted about 30 minutes, showing the different processes that the tea passed through, followed by a nice cup of black tea in the caf√©. We bought a few different types of tea that are produced by Damro - definitely worth trying! Highly recommend if you have an hour on the route from Kandy to Ella.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: My favourite part was the tour and how they really explained it Tips for future Travellers get the tea cake and the chocolate cake it is amazing the tea is absolutely awesome ü§©

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Lovely place to visit, especially if you are a tea afficinato! Many varieties of tea on display and for your putchase.  Frankly I found the tea prices quite high and overpriced....not sure why Silver and Golden tips were about $40 USD for a small box!!! Staff on site to answer questions and help you select our purchase. There is also an indoor and outdoor tea garden.  You are served 1 cup of black tea each person for free and can additionally ourchase a slice of chocolate cake to go along with your tea.  It was an ideal and pleasant experience.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Damro Tea plantation has a big tea estate that caters to local and export needs.¬† We had a brief 20 minutes tour of the factory.¬† Picking of the tea leaves is once a week. The picked leaves are placed in huge belts to dry where huge air blowers blow air to aid in the drying process.¬† This takes about 14 hours of drying. It takes 5 kg fresh leaves to make 1 kg of black tea. Once the leaves are dried they are sent down to the machine where it's rolled and cut as per the requirements.¬† Then they are placed on the table for fermentation where the process of oxidation changes the colour of the tea leaves. No fermentation for green and white tear.¬† Then the leaves are sent to the Dryer machine to stop fermentation to turn to black colour.¬† After this they are sent to the Grading machine for different quality of grading - strong, medium, light.¬† The tour ends with complimentary light black tea. For the huge acres of tea estate and the fact that it's a factory the rates should've been cheaper than the markets. Was very surprised to see such expensive rates.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden

Once the tour is over, you are welcomed into the tea lounge, where you can drink unlimited cups of tea as you want. Whilst the tea and sugar are provided, there is a minimal charge if you want milk. They also sell chocolate and tea cakes, both simply done and lovely. The views are SPECTACULAR, no other word can describe it. They have a nice viewing platform that doubles up for outdoor seating (if the weather permits and its not raining) and the experience is very nice and pleasant. column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This is one of several factories owned by Damro Labookellie and the largest. However, it's still not a huge operation and the walk-through therefore does not take a lot of time - about 30 minutes gets it done. You peer at the operations through glas walls. Nevertheless, i learned quite a bit about tea. The Twining's Orange Pekoe I drink is a milder form of English breakfast black tea etc. This tea factory sends its product to the merchants in Colombo for distribution and export. The capital is also where flavours, such as peppermint are added. The factory does not do any of the flavouring that is the basis for all the options we see in our supermarkets. column11: it was simply a brilliant experience going through the process of making tea. very sporty guide. enjoyed tea with their home made pastries. lovely tea shop where i had to indulge into it. friendly warm services which you definitely get every part of sri lanka. the people of sri lanka are such...warm and friendly. a very memorable trip indeed.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Being tea lover, thought of buying some best tea from a very big tea estate and as promoted by them, I bought both Golden tips and Silver Tips tea. There is no aroma in it and though looks good but taste is not there. So without flavour and aroma, I don't see anything special in their best of the best teas. For people visiting first time in tea estate, will be good experience but suggest not to buy expensive teas from here

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This appears to be a purpose built tourist attraction, but never the less is worth a visit. Pickers work on the tea terraces around the location and the tea making process is well demonstrated within a "mini" factory environment. Tea is served free of charge after the tour, a cake is available at a very small charge. There is a gift shop selling tea, but you are perfectly free to exit the facility without visiting the shop, which is on the opposite side of the building from the exit. Our tour guide spoke excellent English and was very knowledgeable when asked questions. We definitely learned something about the different kinds and grades of tea. It is what it is, It is what it is, but if you want to know how tea is made, then this a free attraction worth visiting.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: As we wanted to visit a tea plantation, our driver suggested we stop off here en route from Nuwara Eliya to Kandy. On arrival, we were met by one of the guides who took us for a tour of the tea factory and explained to us the process of how tea is produced and ends up in our cups. As my husband and I are key tea drinkers, we found it very informative to listen and see the process happen. At the end of the tour, we enjoyed a cup of Damro tea and bought our favourites from the shop; a nice take home for us and the family.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We liked the scenery of tea gardens, but the thing which ruined our visit was the tour of the tea factory, the lady was explaining things in a way as she was doing on a gunpoint, we feel she was tired or bored of repeating the same information to people again and again. We had a bad experience at their tea shop too, my wife was very excited and picked every type of tea available at the shop as we are living in the Middle East and are quite fond of tea, but the attendants at shop were not willing to answer our few questions as they were more interested in tourists with white skins even they weren't buying a fraction of stuff which my wife and I was holding , we tried last time at the payment counter to ask again but the lady at payment counter was also busy with our european ,American friends, finally due to of this continuous neglection in anger my wife dumped all of her stuff at the counter and left without buying anything.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Very traditional tea factory with amazing view over the tea gardens. Tea we bought is excellent quality, prices are not low but worth the quality. Only remark is that the tasting area was not refreshed so we couldn't really taste for choosing the tea we preferred, we bought by type instead.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: A nice experience at one of the biggest tea plantations and factories in Sri Lanka. We saw all the tea process and how it`s made and we tasted a very good tea and eat a delicious chicolate cake.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: We had a very extensive & informative tour of the tea factory & our guide explained it exceptionally well!

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This is a working tea factory, which offers free tours of how they manufacture the variety of teas - and it's worth the 20-30 minutes it takes. The Damro factory is buzzing with tour groups and families delivered by tuk-tuks and taxis. The tour through the factory is interesting, and you can learn a lot about the process. You get a cup of tea at the end (you don't choose which type), and you'll be offered a slice of chocolate cake to go with it. The tea is free, the cake isn't. They won't divulge that until later. It seems pretty likely that tuk tuk and taxi drivers get commissions from the tea shop inside, since the drivers strongly encourage you to buy some tea before you leave. And they hang out in the store to make sure you get that purchase through.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: Damro was the first tea factory we visited in Sri Lanka. It was recommended by several tuktuk drivers and our homestay host. The tour was complimentary and lasted about 20 minutes, as we walked through the factory. We visited on New Year so there were no leaves being blow-dried. Our guide looked tired and recited off a script. She did nonetheless entertain our pesky questions well. After the tour we got to taste a cup each of FF1 tea in the lounge, but sadly we weren‚Äôt particularly impressed. Strangely, there wasn‚Äôt the option to try other types of tea - we would have wanted to try the loose leaf types like OP and BOP which we later discovered were more to our liking. We were, funnily enough, allowed to buy cakes, which admittedly were cheap and decent. Ultimately, as we had liked our host‚Äôs tea, which was from damro, we proceeded to make the mistake of buying too much tea on our first stop. It was only after visiting the Mackwoods museum in Nuwara Eliya‚Äôs city centre that we found out more about the history of Damro - it was a furniture company that had just (as of 2016) ventured into the plantation business, acquiring great swathes of land, including the Labookellie tea lounge, and a significant stake in the Mackwoods brand (the second oldest tea company after the parent company of Lipton). Make what you will of our experience - we still can‚Äôt figure out if we are happy with our purchases 4 days later. But the experience as a whole was somewhat uncanny. The price of tea in the gift shop we found to be average - higher than the Zesta / Lipton types in supermarkets but lower than most single-estate tea companies we visited elsewhere in Sri Lanka. Our advice would be to stay off the teabags (which we tasted and found to be quite ordinary) and stick to the loose leaf teas.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
column11: This is a free and basic tour of a tea factory with a free cup of tea afterwards. It's great Damro does this. I learnt a lot about the tea process. It will take 30 minutes.

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden

column2: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
